definitions.definition: to take control of a country or city and its people by force

examples.text: In 330 BC Persia was conquered by Alexander the Great.
The Roman Empire offered citizenship to its conquered peoples.

definitions.definition: to defeat somebody, especially in a competition, race, etc.

examples.text: The world champion conquered yet another challenger last night.

definitions.definition: to succeed in dealing with or controlling something

examples.text: The only way to conquer a fear is to face it.
Mount Everest was conquered *(= successfully climbed)* in 1953.
He will need to conquer his nerves to progress in this competition.

definitions.definition: to become very popular or successful in a place

examples.text: The band is now setting out to conquer the world.
This is a British film which could conquer the US market.

wordOrigin: Middle English (also in the general sense ‘acquire, attain’): from Old French conquerre, based on Latin conquirere ‘gain, win’, from con- (expressing completion) + quaerere ‘seek’.
